content: How can I help you today?

Honestly, I’m not entirely sure where to start. Things have just been overwhelming at home lately. My wife and I are struggling, mostly because we don’t know how to help our son, and it’s affecting everything—my focus at work, my mood, even spending time with my daughter. It feels like everything is falling apart.

That sounds really heavy and difficult to face. You're carrying so much right now—your concerns about your son, the strain it’s putting on your relationship with your wife, and feeling disconnected in other parts of your life. How are you managing with all of this day to day?

I’m not sure I really am managing. Most days, it feels like I’m just going through the motions. I’m either caught up in trying to deal with my son’s behavior or arguing with my wife about what to do next. And when I’m not doing that, I’m drained and just trying to make it through work without falling apart. I don’t even know how to relax anymore.

It's understandable that you're feeling drained and unsure how to relax in the midst of so much stress and conflict. Balancing your son's challenges, your relationship, and your work must feel overwhelming. What was relaxing or fulfilling for you before things started feeling this way?

I honestly can’t even remember. Maybe spending time with my daughter, or having a quiet evening with my wife, but it’s been so long since I’ve felt relaxed that I don’t know if those things would feel the same anymore. Right now, even the things I used to enjoy just feel like more effort.

It sounds like the stress and exhaustion have overshadowed the things that used to bring you joy, leaving you questioning whether they’d even help now. There’s a lot weighing on you, and it’s taking away the energy for those moments you valued before. What do you think would need to change for you to feel like you could reconnect with those experiences or find new ways to relax?

I think I’d need to feel like there’s progress—like we’re actually helping my son and not just endlessly stuck. I’d need my wife and I to be on the same page, instead of constantly arguing. Right now, it feels like I can’t even begin to think about enjoying anything unless we figure those things out first.

It sounds like the tension around figuring out how to support your son and the disagreements with your wife are blocking you from finding peace or enjoyment in other parts of life. That desire for progress and unity feels really important to you. What do you envision as progress, or how would things look if you and your wife were on the same page?

I think progress would be seeing some change in my son’s behavior, something that shows us we’re on the right track. And I guess with my wife, it would mean being able to really talk to each other without it turning into a fight—actually feeling like a team again, instead of being at odds all the time. That’s what I’d want.

You're looking for signs of forward movement, whether it's visible changes in your son's behavior or feeling connected and collaborative with your wife again. Those are meaningful goals, and they show how deeply you care about your family and working together through this. What do you think is standing in the way of making that kind of progress right now?

I think what's in the way is that my wife and I don’t know how to approach things the same way. We have different ideas about what will help our son, and that leads to a lot of tension. It’s like we both want to fix things, but we’re pulling in opposite directions. That makes it hard to even start moving forward.

It sounds like both you and your wife deeply care about helping your son, but the differing approaches are creating conflict and holding you both back from feeling aligned. It's clear that the desire to work together is there, but the “how” feels stuck. What do you think could help bring your ideas more into alignment or open up better communication between you?

Maybe if we had someone to help us figure out a plan together, like a mediator or someone experienced with these kinds of situations. I don’t think we’re listening to each other anymore, and having that outside perspective might stop things from turning into an argument every time we talk about it. Honestly, I don’t even know where to start on my own.

It’s insightful that you're recognizing the need for support and that having a neutral, experienced perspective might help you and your wife come together with a shared plan for your son. That openness to seeking guidance shows how committed you are to improving things for your family. Would you want to explore ways to find that kind of help, or is there anything else you'd like to focus on first?

It’s insightful that you're recognizing the need for support and that having a neutral, experienced perspective might help you and your wife come together with a shared plan for your son. That openness to seeking guidance shows how committed you are to improving things for your family. Have you both considered working with a family therapist or counselor to help navigate these conversations?

Family therapy could definitely be a helpful step, especially if you're looking for a neutral space where both you and your wife can feel heard and supported in finding common ground. It might give you a better way to communicate and work toward solutions together. Is that something you’d be open to exploring further? Or are there other possible steps you’d want to consider first?

Family therapy could be a good idea, but honestly, I hadn’t thought about it much. I guess I’ve been so skeptical about therapy in general that I didn’t think it could actually help. But if it could get us to a place where we’re not fighting all the time and actually making progress, then maybe it’s worth a shot.

It's understandable to feel skeptical about therapy, especially when things feel overwhelming and uncertain. But it’s encouraging to hear that you’re willing to consider it for the sake of building better communication and making progress as a family. It’s clear how much you care about moving forward together. Is there anything holding you back from giving it a try, or would you feel ready to explore it?

It's totally understandable to feel hesitant, especially since all of this is new territory. But it really sounds like you’re willing to try whatever it takes to help your family, and that openness can go a long way. If you decide to explore family therapy, it might really help to have that supportive space to work on coming together. Do you think your wife would be on board with the idea?

You’re willing to consider something outside of your comfort zone to support your family, and that’s a significant step. Whether or not your wife would be open to family therapy is an important question—it could be an opportunity for both of you to find that shared foundation and understand each other better. How do you feel about bringing up the idea with her?
